data.name: DBA (Double Barrel Ale)
data.description: Our flagship brew highlights barrel-fermented batches from our patented Firestone Union blended with beer fermented in stainless steel.  It opens with a biscuity toasted malt aroma and a hint of oak and vanilla.  Pale malts create a smooth malty middle with ribbons of caramel, English toffee and toasted oak.  A tribute to English pales traditionally fermented in cask.

available.name: Year Round
available.description: Available year round as a staple beer.

style.name: Special Bitter or Best Bitter
style.description: Special bitter is more robust than ordinary bitter. It has medium body and medium residual malt sweetness. It is deep gold to copper colored. Hop bitterness should be medium and absent of harshness. Hop flavor and aroma character may be evident at the brewer's discretion. Mild carbonation traditionally characterizes draft-cask versions, but in bottled versions, a slight increase in carbon dioxide content is acceptable. Fruity-ester character is acceptable in aroma and flavor. Diacetyl (butterscotch character) is acceptable and characteristic when at very low levels. The absence of diacetyl is also acceptable. Chill haze is allowable at cold temperatures. (English and American hop character may be specified in subcategories.)

breweries.name: Firestone Walker Brewing Company
breweries.description: Founded in 1996 by Adam Firestone (aka the Bear) & David Walker (aka the Lion), Firestone Walker Brewing Company began as a small brewery with roots in wine country on California’s Central Coast. Now a regional brewery, our singular purpose remains – to craft ever better beer.  Passionately in pursuit of the perfect beer…and never satisfied.

data.name: Double DBA
data.description: DDBA is our flagship beer brewed at double strength.  It is amazingly similar in many respects to our barrel fermented DBA and possesses everything we love about that beer times two.  English caramel malts lend rich toffee character that pairs well with assertive medium toast American oak barrels.

data.name: Double Old Thumper
data.description:
Double Old Thumper is the big brother of the British Grand Champion beer Old Thumper. Available in the United States under a unique agreement between England’s Ringwood Brewery and Shipyard Brewing Company, Double Old Thumper is a real beast of a beer! Created by Shipyard’s master brewer Alan Pugsley, Double Old Thumper delivers a spicy hop aroma and a brilliant deep copper hue. This beer has a complex malty finish with a dry Simcoe Hop bite.

Malt: 2-row British Pale Ale, Crystal, Chocolate
Hops: Challenger, Progress, Goldings, Simcoe
Yeast: Top-Fermenting English
Color: Deep Copper Hue
OG: 1.108
Food Pairings: Short Ribs, Lamb, Hearty Stews, Casseroles
Available: 22oz Bottles, Draft

breweries.name: Shipyard Brewing
breweries.description: Since 1994, Shipyard Brewing Company has been brewing fine quality products with a wide range of style profiles. We use only top quality ingredients and pride ourselves on the consistency and freshness of our products. All our beer is hand crafted from recipes developed by master brewer Alan Pugsley, one of the most influential people in the craft brewing movement in North America.  Shipyard is available in 35+ states around the country and markets for our freshly brewed, hand-crafted beers continue to expand.

data.name: Dreadnought
data.description: A rich ruby colored premium bitter with a well rounded fullness of malt and deep strength of hop bitterness.

data.name: Dying Vines Old Brick Bitter
data.description: Named for Linden’s building and our pride in old Oakland and the East Bay. Old Brick Bitter, our Special Bitter, is a malty, full bodied English style Pale Ale with a dry and hoppy finish. We use all English pale and specialty malts finishing with a generous amount of East Kent Golding hops making this session beer perfect for cask, beer engine and traditional draught service, A REAL ALE- 4.5% a.b.v. .

data.name: Endangered Sea Bear
data.description: This complex, malt-driven beer is the favorite child of our brewers. Strong in alcohol, with some sweet flavors persisting, this beer exemplifies the best in taste combined with a smooth finish.

breweries.name: Toasted and Tapped Brewery and Restaurant Flowery Branch
breweries.nameShortDisplay: Toasted and Tapped Brewery and Restaurant Flowery Branch
breweries.description: Toasted and Tapped began as a challenge to a group of friends.  The challenge was to take our combined skills and create a brewpub that excels in providing tasty beers, inspired food, and excellent customer service.  After meeting in college, the group entered the work place to refine the skills required to create and operate a successful brewpub.  In January of 2010, with inspired council from family, Paul Coggins relocated to Georgia to focus the group on one purpose.  With the help of God, the group was charged to create the best dining experience for the community.  After many months of construction, permitting, setbacks, and discoveries; Toasted and Tapped opened its doors to the public on November 26th, 2010.  We at Toasted and Tapped are excited to offer the best food, beer, and service we can to the community which gives us so much.

data.name: English Bitter
data.description: Maris Otter malt and East Kent Golding hops are used to make a fine example of an English Bitter. Conditioned in casks with no forced carbonation, our bitter is served from hand pump giving it a smooth mouth feel and creamy head. As the style dictates, it is served less cold than Australian beers and has less carbonation. Brewed from a hundred year old recipe and will sure bring back memories of travels through the British Isles.

breweries.name: Flat Rock Brew Cafe
breweries.description:
We are very proud of what the Flat Rock Brew Cafe stands for, and with our dedicated and friendly staff, look forward to seeing all our friends, locals and appreciators of beer, wine and cider!
 
Beer is certainly our focus and our aim is for customers to walk out of the cafe more enlightened about this great beverage, than when they came in.  The Flat Rock Brew Cafe is home to a working 'nano-brewery' and a member of the Craft Beer Industry Association. The brewhouse itself consists of a Braumeister system, one very familiar to home brewers. German made, it provides efficiency in the brewing process and was selected for its compact design. For those who want to really explore the world of beer, we offer unique beer tasting events and brewery tours.
 
Something that is important to us is supporting the local community and since opening, we have been involved in many fund raising events for a number of local schools and businesses. We have also become the venue of choice for community meetings from sporting clubs to pre-schools.
 
Our great range of wines and ciders are mostly Australian as we aim to support local producers.
 
Our food is highly regarded and compliments our range of beverages. From share plates to weekly curry specials, there's always something for everyone including vegetarian and gluten-free options.
 
We truly appreciate the support you have all given us since opening and we look forward to seeing you here at Flat Rock Brew Cafe in the near future.

data.name: English Special Bitter
data.description: Our take on a classic English style. We brew this beer with a combination of caramel, wheat and special roasted malts to give it a unique malty body. A classic English style yeast lightens this beer up with hints of fruitiness. Moderately hopped to make this a balanced, sessionable beer.

breweries.name: The Dayton Beer Company
breweries.description:
The Dayton Beer Company is a multiple Award Winning Brewery and was voted  Dayton’s Best Microbrewery in 2014.  Our Pilot Brewery and Taproom is located in Kettering, Ohio.  We are in the process of opening our Production Brewery and Bier Hall in Downtown Dayton.

We are proud to be the first true Microbrewery in the Dayton area in over 50 years. All of our beer is hand-crafted with no automation in small batches with our own unique recipes. This allows us to create beers tailored with our own vision and style.

The Dayton Beer Company remembers all those who came before us and treasure their legacy by naming our core brews after them. Be sure to look for us at your favorite watering holes and retailers. As always, we encourage everyone to stop by our brewery to enjoy the fruits of our labor and relax and have fun in our cozy tap-room.

data.name: ESB Ale
data.description: This ESB is a classic British extra special bitter made fresh with an American slant. A beautiful copper color with an amber head, this classic style features five different malts, including imported English malts, and three hop varieties. The rich malty start features caramel notes that develop into a smooth, pleasurable hop finish.

breweries.name: Flying Fish Brewing Company
breweries.description:
When Gene Muller founded Flying Fish Brewing Co. in 1995, he did so first on the World Wide Web - making it the world's first virtual microbrewery. That early Web site helped generate positive press coverage and helped attract the investors needed to make the virtual brewery a real one. Muller said the idea was to make the Web site “This Old House meets the World Wide Web”—letting people go behind the taps and see the thousands of details needed to put a microbrewery together.

He also wanted to give beer lovers a chance, via their computers, to roll up their cyber-sleeves and help build the brewery. The site let beer lovers help select and name beers, design t-shirts and labels, volunteer to be a taste-tester and even apply for a job as a brewer. Visitors to the Web site can sign up for FlyingFishMail a monthly e-mail newsletter which now boasts more than 12,000 subscribers.

Muller, who got into the brewing field to become a brewer, trained at Chicago's Siebel Institute of Technology, America's oldest brewing school. He quickly realized someone was going to have to run the day-to-day business of the brewery and now serves as President and Head Janitor (though not necessarily in that order).

Flying Fish Brewing Company is located in Somerdale, New Jersey, approximately seven miles east of Philadelphia. In a state that once boasted 50 breweries, it is the first microbrewery in Southern New Jersey and the first new brewery built in that part of the state in more than half a century. From its opening in late 1996, Flying Fish has tripled its capacity and become the largest of the approximately 20 craft breweries in the state.

breweries.name: Trinity Brewhouse
breweries.description:
Always fresh, always crisp.
Crafted with the finest quality hops from around the world, and filtered Scituate Reservoir water from right here in Little Rhody.

The beers, ales, porters and stouts available at the Brewhouse Pub are brewed on premises - ensuring a high quality product that is always satisfying and never flat.

Our Brewmaster takes great pride in providing our customers with the freshest beer in the city.
If we were any fresher...you'd slap us!

Stop by for a pint or two in house - or grab a Growler To Go and enjoy great Trinity Brewhouse Beer at your own leisure.

data.name: Firkin Best Bitter
data.description:
Having a wedding, party or celebration? Well a Harveys Firkin is the ideal way to set your event apart from the rest. Our draught Best is a superbly balanced bitter with a prominent hop character. Our most famous and popular brand - it makes up over 90% of our total brewing capacity. Winner of the Champion Best Bitter of Britain title at CAMRA's Great British Beers Festival in 2005 and 2006.

Please note: We also sell this product as 'Bright' beer, which has a shorter shelf life of 2-3 days but does not require settling before consumption. Call our shop on 01273 480 217 for further details and to order.

breweries.name: Isle of Purbeck Brewery
breweries.description:
Established in 2003, the award winning Isle of Purbeck Brewery started brewing at the gateway to Dorsets world heritage Jurassic coast, nestled in the Purbeck Hills overlooking the clear blue sea of Studland Bay.
Building on the success of our renowned Fossil Fuel under the expert guidance of master brewer Dan Thomasson, Jack, Pippa and the IOPB team have grown the range to 5 core beers, encompassing a delicious spectrum of styles and tastes.
Our approach to making the beer has always been straightforward. First of all we make it all by hand in the traditional way, that way we make sure each part of the brew is perfect. Secondly we dont cut any corners on ingredients.
We use the best that England can provide. And last but not least, we aim to provide exceptional personal service in the finest traditions of a family run brewery.

data.name: Friggin in the Riggin Tasting Notes
data.nameDisplay: Friggin in the Riggin Tasting Notes
data.description: A premium bitter that is mid brown in colour and has a smooth malt flavour with a bitter sweet aftertaste.Friggin in the Riggin is a phrase used by Sailors who spent many months at sea away from home, it was time spent fooling around away from the ships duties. The words have been immortalized in history by the Sex Pistols releasing a song with this name. See also: www.frigginintheriggin.co.uk

breweries.name: Nelson Brewery
breweries.description:
The brewery was first brought to the Historic Dockyard at Chatham as the Flagship Brewery in 1995 where it established a five barrel kit brewing up to 100 firkins a week. All the ales have nautical themed names to gel with the surroundings in which it is brewed


In 2003 the brewery was bought and renamed the Nelson Brewing Company to fall in line with the most famous naval hero of all time 'Admiral Horatio Nelson' and that his flagship 'The Victory' was built here in Chatham Dockyard.

In July 2006 the brewery was purchased by Piers Macdonald. Piers has over 20 years experience in the brewing industry and is passionate to keep the traditions of Kent brewing alive. Using the best ingredients and the finest Kent hops, combined with the expertise and dedication of his brewing staff, Piers plans to build on the brewery's already growing reputation as the provider of some of the tastiest ales on the market.

Now brewing from a seven and a half barrel kit and regularly having over a dozen ales of various strengths and taste available, the brewery is sure to have a beer to suit all!

data.name: Fripp
data.description: American Bitter. 4.5% Brewed with caramel malts, rye and a copious amount of Munich malt. Hopped with Columbus and Cascade. A beer to be drank by the pint .

breweries.name: Tired Hands Brewing Company
breweries.description:
We value local over imported, small batches over mass production, and striking a successful balance between giving back to our community and personal profit. Localization guides everything we do, from sourcing raw ingredients and materials, to employing area talent.

Tired Hands Brewing Company will operate at 16 Ardmore Avenue, Ardmore Pa, on a six barrel brewhouse. We will focus our brewing on two very broad styles of beers that hold a special place in my heart: Belgian/French farmhouse ales and American hop-forward ales.

All cheeses, meats, and seasonal produce served at our cafe (simple and satisfying fare from honest local producers) will be sourced from within 100 miles of our brewery.

data.name: FSB
data.description: A traditional Marris Otter base with adjunct Crystal malts provides a smooth grain flavor, complimented well by roasted barley. The malt is balanced, but not overtaken, by Goldings and Willamette hops. There is a soft, crisp finish with a pleasant smell reminiscent of dry hay. A beer that drinks easily without lacking in flavor.

breweries.name: D.L. Geary Brewing Company
breweries.description: The D.L. Geary Brewing Company was incorporated in October, 1983 by David and Karen Geary who shared the vision of producing world class products on a small scale for local and regional consumption. At that time, there were only 13 so-called microbreweries in the United States, almost all of them in California and the Pacific Northwest. In the winter of 1984, David Geary began a period of training and research in Scotland and England. With the help of Peter Maxwell Stuart, a Scottish nobleman and brewer who arranged introductions and itineraries, he worked in a half-dozen small commercial breweries from the highlands of Scotland to the south coast of England.

breweries.name: Roc Brewing Company
breweries.description: When Roc Brewing Co. began in the crisp cellaring walls of a suburban Rochester basement, they never imaged the future that was set forward. The ever infectious brewing bug had bitten both homebrewers Jonathan Mervine and Chris Spinelli. From the time the yeast was pitched it was unanimous this was their future. Joined by the emboldened encouragement of Chris’ mom and third partner Patty Spinelli, she was hooked by first sip. The new family began their many trials and tribulations of brewing, three tier law, legalese and to much to their chagrin ROC Brewing Co. was founded.

locations.name: Main Brewery
locations.hoursOfOperation:
Brewery Production
Monday – Saturday: 8am – 4pm

Tasting Room/Tap Room
Thursday – Friday: 5pm – 11pm
Saturday: 3pm – 11pm

data.name: Golden Newt
data.description:
Pale in colour with prominent hoppy palate and full flavoured finish, Golden Newt is a pale session bitter of 4.1% ABV.
 
The beer has a prominent hop character; a blend of Fuggles, Goldings and Cascade has been used in the recipe to bring the delicate hop flavour and aroma to the fore.  The use of Cascade gives a pleasing citrus aroma.
 
Finest pale Maris Otter malt has been blended with wheat malt and rye crystal to provide a full flavoured beer.  The lavish use of late hop dominates the malt flavour and results in a satisfying pint.

style.name: Special Bitter or Best Bitter
style.description: Special bitter is more robust than ordinary bitter. It has medium body and medium residual malt sweetness. It is deep gold to copper colored. Hop bitterness should be medium and absent of harshness. Hop flavor and aroma character may be evident at the brewer's discretion. Mild carbonation traditionally characterizes draft-cask versions, but in bottled versions, a slight increase in carbon dioxide content is acceptable. Fruity-ester character is acceptable in aroma and flavor. Diacetyl (butterscotch character) is acceptable and characteristic when at very low levels. The absence of diacetyl is also acceptable. Chill haze is allowable at cold temperatures. (English and American hop character may be specified in subcategories.)

breweries.name: Elgood's Brewery
breweries.description:
Elgood’s Brewery is a family business established over 200 years ago and run by the Elgood family since 1878. You can find out more about our history here.
 
Today’s Chairman is Nigel Elgood, who ran the brewery as managing director from 1968 to 2002.
 
In that year he handed over the running of the business to the eldest of his three daughters Belinda, who continues as the managing director; while her two sisters Claire and Jennifer are directors. We are very proud of our family history and its association with Elgood’s Brewery.

data.name: Gordon Bennett
data.description: Light chestnut beer with a biscuity finish

breweries.name: Belvoir Brewery
breweries.description: Belvoir Brewery brews eight regular beers, including the founding beer Beaver Bitter, and various specials, and also brews Shipstone's Original Ale and Shipstone's Gold Star Blonde Ale.  They supply over 275 pubs in a 50 mile radius and local shops with their Melton Red.

data.name: Gowanus Bay Bitters
data.description: Beer made by brewer Pete Dickson, in honor of the great Gowanus Bay. This beer is a straightforward English Bitter-style recipe, fermented with an abundance of Maris Otter pale malt with a healthy contribution of Fuggle hops. However, it is fermented clean and cold with a neutral ale yeast, and dry hopped heavily in the conditioning carboys. Expect aromatic, floral and toasted biscuit malt flavors.

breweries.name: Sixpoint Brewery
breweries.description:
Sixpoint Craft Ales was founded in 2004 by Shane Welch, a former homebrewer that originally grew up in Milwaukee. The microbrewery is located in a 7,000-square-foot (650 m2) factory in in Red Hook, Brooklyn that formerly manufactured filing cabinets. Sixpoint began business by only distributing kegs to local bars and restaurants; instead of bottling its beer, filling growlers at bars were the only way for customers to drink the beer at their homes. 

In 2011 Sixpoint launched initial canned  offerings of 16 oz, year-round styles Sweet Action, Bengali Tiger, Righteous Ale and The Crisp.  Further releases have included the 12 oz Resin and 3Beans, as well as 16oz seasonal offerings such as Apollo and Autumnation.

data.name: Hampshire Rose
data.description: Awarded by Henry V on the battlefield of Agincourt to the Archers of Hampshire. Visually tempting, Rose is a carefully selected blend of Maris Otter and roasted barley. Brewed using four choice hops; Target, Hercules, Nugget and Galena producing a truly hoppy finish, worthy of any Kings’ approval.

breweries.name: Itchen Valley Brewery
breweries.description:
Founded in 1997 by two businessmen at the Christening of their Godson Dugald Rhodes. The Godfathers, pleased with their honorary responsibility, thought carefully for the future of little Dugald.

Several pints of mediocre ale later the idea for forming a brewery and making their own beer began to take hold. A toast was made and within weeks a site (wholly inadequate) was found and the equipment (too big for the site) was bought.

The first brew, Godfathers, won the Bronze Award for best ale in Britain the following year at the Great British Beer Festival.

16 years, 30 million pints and a brewery relocation later IVB continues to thrive. Situated in the heart of Hampshire we produce an unrivalled range of award winning real ales with pure Hampshire water, yeast and barley along with the finest hops around the country and world.

Godson Dugald is as yet too young to enjoy his beer birthright, but we’re sure he will.

data.name: Hello World
data.description: The lights flicker on as the steam boiler fires up and begins to hum. The stereo crackles to life and the doors swing open. At long last, we’re finally ready. Hello World.
data.foodPairings: This light-bodied special bitter is best paired with similarily mild dishes such as fish and chips. It makes for an excellent ploughman’s lunch when accompanied by freshly baked bread and mellow, buttery cheeses.

data.name: HSB
data.description: Hale’s Special Bitter, or “HSB”, is a complex, deep amber colored ale that blends a silky smooth body with an intriguing hop aroma. Its nitrogen conditioning gives it a very creamy mouthfeel. HSB emulates the famous “special bitters” found in Great Britain.

breweries.name: Hales Ales Brewery and Pub
breweries.description:
Founded by Mike Hale in 1983, Hale's Ales is the Northwest's 3rd oldest and longest running independently owned brewery in the Northwest. Hale's built its long standing reputation by brewing small batch, full flavored ales using traditional English brewing methods.

An innovator from the start, Hale's was the first craft brewery to introduce Seasonal, Cask Conditioned and Nitrogen Conditioned ales to the region. Hale's goal is to stay true to what the craft brewing "revolution" is all about: crafting fresh, locally brewed ales of the very finest quality. Cheers from Hale's Ales!

data.name: I'm Not Bitter
data.description: The mild fruitiness from the yeast and caramel imparted from the malt balance nicely with the mild bitterness and earthy flavor from the English hops. As the name implies only the best ingredients were used.

data.name: Jekyll’s Best Bitter
data.description: A copper colored, medium bodied English style ale. The delicate malty sweetness is nicely balanced with subtle English hops. Very smooth and drinkable, and not at all bitter- (see Hedrick and Hagan ESB).

data.name: John Smith's Extra Smooth
data.description:
John Smith’s Extra Smooth was launched in 1993 and is now the nation's number 1 ale.
The boffins say it has a distinct cereal character, with malty, caramel notes being complemented by some fruitiness. But we just think it’s a right good pint.
Extra Smooth is available in draught at the pub or in cans to be enjoyed at home (both 3.6% ABV).
Plus you can also get John Smith’s Extra Cold on draught; the same great taste, but colder, we don't muck about with names see.

breweries.name: John Smith's Brewery
breweries.description: Founded in 1758 and originally known as the Backhouse & Hartley Brewery, John Smith's Brewery traces it's roots back to Tadcaster, Yorkshire, England. The company is famous for it's Bitter and Extra Smooth Ales, which have been amongst Britain's best selling ales since the 1990s.

data.name: John Willie’s
data.description: Named after Mr JW Lees himself, this highly coloured robust beer is our original premium bitter. It’s a great pint that drinks smoothly and gives a nutty finish. Made from ale and crystal malt, Northdown and Goldings hops, it is a well-balanced, full-bodied beer. First brewed for bottle in 1999 then perfected for cask in 2008.

breweries.name: Raw Brewing Company
breweries.description: Raw Brewing Company was created from a passion for real ale and an idea that became reality. After several years of enjoying real ale David decided to have a go himself as a hobby to see if he could produce quality real ale. After several months it was clear that the product was good with the assistance from an army of tasters! It was time then to turn this passion and idea into reality Raw Brewing Company was born.

data.name: Kentish Reserve
data.description: A Premium Bitter the color of burnished copper. Crystal malt and a Goldings-led hop blend bring into being flavors of peaches and plums, ending on a note of rich ruby port.

data.name: Kidder Special Bitter
data.description: This bitter was first brewed in 1998 to commemorate the annual Pecos Conference and named after famed archeologist A.V. Kidder. This beer has a complex fruity “nutmeg” aroma and flavor derived from centennial & cascade hops, blended with a rich satisfying caramel malt profile.

breweries.name: Big Time Brewing Company
breweries.description:
Big Time's brewery is a 14 barrel JV Northwest system consisting of a gas fired brew kettle, an infusion mash tun with mixer, a hot liquor back, a wort cooler, (5) 14 barrel fermenters, (1) bright beer tank, and (20) 7 bbl serving tanks.  

We sell 85% of our beer at the pub but do wholesale a limited number of kegs to a dozen or so Seattle area taverns. We currently brew approximately 1,300 barrels of beer per year

breweries.name: Thr3e Wise Men Brewing Company
breweries.description:
Located in beautiful Broad Ripple in Indianapolis, Indiana, Scotty's Thr3e Wise Men Brewing Company opened on January 17, 2011. Thr3e Wise Men will not only brew beer but will also be serving pizza, appetizers and desserts.
Thr3e Wise Men greets its guests with a classic lodge feel - exposed beams, concrete floors and warm wood walls.  Of course, Scotty prides himself on staying ahead of the technology curve and wanted to be the first one of the first Indiana restaurants to adorn dining room tables with Apple iPads so customers are able to learn more about Thr3e Wise Men Brewing Co., the beers, and Scotty's two other restaurant concepts.

breweries.name: The ChopHouse & Brewery
breweries.description: As a popular gathering place, our pride is in serving American steakhouse classics, paired with the city’s finest handcrafted beers brewed on site. But we are much more than a steakhouse, offering a great experience at an affordable price, with hand-cut chops, fresh seafood and an extensive wine list, all in a unique turn of the century bank transformed into one of Washington’s hot spots.

style.description: Special bitter is more robust than ordinary bitter. It has medium body and medium residual malt sweetness. It is deep gold to copper colored. Hop bitterness should be medium and absent of harshness. Hop flavor and aroma character may be evident at the brewer's discretion. Mild carbonation traditionally characterizes draft-cask versions, but in bottled versions, a slight increase in carbon dioxide content is acceptable. Fruity-ester character is acceptable in aroma and flavor. Diacetyl (butterscotch character) is acceptable and characteristic when at very low levels. The absence of diacetyl is also acceptable. Chill haze is allowable at cold temperatures. (English and American hop character may be specified in subcategories.)

breweries.name: Keltek Brewery
breweries.description: The Keltek Brewery is a multi award winning Brewery situated in Redruth, Cornwall.

data.name: McNellie's Pub Ale
data.description: Inspired by the house ales found in the pubs of Great Britain and Ireland, McNellie’s Pub Ale is a traditional ale brewed in the style of a Best Bitter. Various maltings of two-row barley are joined with American Glacier hops to give this beer its color, complexity, and a bit of a New World twist. The Old World character present in this ale is largely influenced by its yeast, which originates in the port city of Hull, East Yorkshire, England. McNellie’s Pub Ale pairs excellent with fish & chips (of course), Roast Beef, Steak, Pork, Grilled Chicken, and Barbeque.

available.name: Year Round
available.description: Available year round as a staple beer.

breweries.name: Marshall Brewing Company
breweries.description: Marshall Brewing Company’s goal is to bring the art, quality, and enjoyment of craft brewing to Oklahoma. MBC does this by operating with a highly trained and educated staff that possesses a passion for top quality brewing and will settle for nothing less. The company aims to be known as the premiere brewery in Oklahoma and to be respected on the regional and national markets as well. MBC’s development goals are for steady growth without ever sacrificing quality, which is the cornerstone of the product line.

data.name: Mighty Maximus
data.description: This beer has an amped up bitterness that sets it apart from other bitters. Mighty Maximus has a rounded malt aroma with a bready, roasty smell and slight caramel sweetness. This vigorous session beer has a robust full-bodied mouth feel tasting of toffee and toasty malt character. The elevated bitterness at the finish completes this beer leaving the taste bigger than perceived.
data.foodPairings: Our Premium Bitter pairs with a wide variety of food. The robust body can sustain roast chicken or pork, fish and chips, as well as other grilled meats, as long as they’re not too spicy. Another good choice is Thai food, as long as it’s not overwhelmingly hot.  As you move to cheeses try some Lancashire or Leicester. English Bitter pairs very well with some Oatmeal-raisin-walnut cookies.

data.name: Misconception Amber Ale
data.description: If you miss our Red Medicine, this should help you feel better! It's the next generation of RX.

breweries.name: Bitter Ester's Brewhouse
breweries.description: We are a Small Artisan Nano-Brewery!  We specialize in English inspired American Ales and Belgian-style Farmhouse Ales.  We use only the finest barley, grown and malted all over the world.  We use hops that are grown all over the world as well.  If you are noticing a theme our beers are unique to each time we brew therefore we need to tap the expert farmers and craftsman worldwide to get these wonderful and unique ingredients.  We have six ales on draft at any one time and our Dry stout and Brown Ale are the only reoccurring beers.  We brew farmhouse ales that are different every batch we brew.

data.name: Monkmans Slaughter
data.description:
Champion Beer of Britain - GOLD MEDAL WINNER YEAR 2000 - Strong Beer Category

A full bodied powerful brew, dark brown with a very distinct malty flavour using finest crushed pale, crystal and roasted malts, which combine perfectly with Kent Challenger and Goldings hops. Very strong and extremely moreish.

Named after Mr. Monkman who grows the malt, and Mr. Slaughter our brewer and chemist. Unwittingly we have given the two chaps an ideal alibi: they now feel duty bound to sit at the end of the bar and check that the end product is worthy of their names!
